qas.question: What pigment did 19th century artists use that was deemed unfavorably?
What did bitumen when used as a paint not do correctly?
What did even limited use of bitumen do to damage paintings?
What artist's work i considered to be an example of the damaging effects of bitumen?
What major problem did bitumen as a pigment show itself to be?
What was the nemesis of many singers during the 19th century?
What was the nemesis of many artists during the 21th century?
Bitumen proved stable for use in what type of painting?
Bitumen will always fully solidify when what?

plausible_answers.text: Théodore Géricault's Raft of the Medusa (1818–1819),

qas.question: What is an example of the destructiveness of linseed oil?

context: <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>Bitumen<b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> was the nemesis of many artists during the 19th century. Although widely used for a time, it ultimately proved <a4_0>unstable<a4_0/> for use in <b7_0>oil<b7_0/> painting, especially when mixed with the most common diluents, such as linseed oil, varnish and turpentine. Unless <b8_0>thoroughly diluted<b8_0/>, bitumen never fully <a1_0>solidifies<a1_0/> and will in time corrupt the other pigments with which it comes into contact. The use of bitumen as a glaze to set in shadow or mixed with other colors to render a darker tone resulted in the eventual <a2_0>deterioration<a2_0/> of many paintings, for instance those of Delacroix. Perhaps the most famous example of the destructiveness of bitumen is <a3_0><b9_0>Théodore Géricault's<a3_0/> Raft of the Medusa (1818–1819),<b9_0/> where his use of bitumen caused the brilliant colors to degenerate into dark greens and blacks and the paint and canvas to buckle.
